items.text: I would rather let the other person have their way than damage the relationship.
items.rationale: Prioritizing the relationship over one's own needs is a core feature of the accommodating style.

items.text: When someone feels strongly about something, I tend to give in to keep the peace.
items.rationale: Yielding to others' strong preferences to maintain harmony is classic accommodating behavior.

items.text: I often put other people's needs ahead of my own during disagreements.
items.rationale: Self-sacrifice in conflict is a defining characteristic of the accommodating style.

items.text: If conceding a point makes someone else happy, I'm usually willing to do it.
items.rationale: Willingness to concede for others' happiness reflects high cooperativeness and low assertiveness.

items.text: People sometimes tell me I'm too agreeable and should stand up for myself more.
items.rationale: Feedback about excessive agreeableness is a behavioral marker of chronic accommodation.

items.text: I believe that preserving goodwill is more important than winning an argument.
items.rationale: Valuing goodwill over winning directly reflects the accommodating orientation.

items.text: When a colleague is upset, I'll agree with their position even if I privately disagree.
items.rationale: Suppressing one's own view to soothe another's emotions is a hallmark of accommodation.

items.text: I find it easy to defer to others because harmony matters more to me than being right.
items.rationale: Explicit preference for harmony over correctness maps directly to accommodating.

items.text: I tend to go along with the group decision even when I have reservations.
items.rationale: Going along despite reservations reflects yielding one's own position for group cohesion.

items.text: I'd rather sacrifice my own preferences than see someone else feel disappointed.
items.rationale: Sacrificing preferences to prevent others' disappointment is core accommodating behavior.

items.text: In a disagreement, I usually let the other person's argument take priority over mine.
items.rationale: Consistently deferring to others' arguments reflects low assertiveness and high cooperativeness.

items.text: I often apologize first in a conflict, even when I don't think I was entirely wrong.
items.rationale: Preemptive apology regardless of fault is a behavioral indicator of accommodation.

items.text: Sometimes I agree to things I don't really want just to avoid making someone uncomfortable.
items.rationale: While clearly yielding, the motivation of avoiding discomfort introduces some overlap with avoidance.

items.text: I think it's generous to let others have their way—it shows you care about them.
items.rationale: Framing yielding as generosity is accommodating, but the philosophical tone adds slight ambiguity.

items.text: I'd rather drop my own concerns than push back and risk creating tension.
items.rationale: Dropping concerns to avoid tension could reflect accommodating (yielding for the other) or avoiding (withdrawing from conflict entirely).

items.text: When a conflict arises, my first instinct is to walk away and let things cool down.
items.rationale: Physically withdrawing from conflict is a primary behavioral marker of the avoiding style.

items.text: I tend to sidestep disagreements whenever possible.
items.rationale: Sidestepping disagreements reflects the core avoidance strategy of not engaging.

items.text: I often postpone dealing with difficult conversations, hoping the issue will resolve itself.
items.rationale: Postponement and hoping problems disappear are classic avoidance behaviors.

items.text: I feel very uncomfortable when people around me are in conflict, so I try to stay out of it.
items.rationale: Discomfort with conflict leading to non-engagement is a defining feature of avoidance.

items.text: I'd rather change the subject than address a disagreement head-on.
items.rationale: Deflecting through topic change is a well-recognized avoidance tactic.

items.text: If I sense a conversation is heading toward an argument, I'll find a reason to leave.
items.rationale: Preemptive physical withdrawal from potential conflict is textbook avoidance.

items.text: I believe most conflicts aren't worth the energy it takes to engage in them.
items.rationale: Devaluing conflict engagement reflects the cognitive framework underlying avoidance.

items.text: People close to me sometimes complain that I shut down when things get tense.
items.rationale: Others noticing emotional shutdown during tension is a behavioral consequence of avoidance.

items.text: I often pretend a problem doesn't exist rather than confront it directly.
items.rationale: Denial of problems to prevent confrontation is a core avoidance mechanism.

items.text: I rarely bring up issues that bother me because I don't want to start a fight.
items.rationale: Suppressing concerns to prevent conflict initiation is a hallmark of avoidance.

items.text: When two friends are arguing, I make sure not to take sides or get involved.
items.rationale: Refusing involvement in others' conflicts reflects avoidance of conflict engagement.

items.text: I find that ignoring minor irritations is usually the best strategy.
items.rationale: Deliberately ignoring irritations rather than addressing them is avoidance behavior.

items.text: I sometimes let small issues pile up because I never address them in the moment.
items.rationale: Accumulation of unaddressed issues is a consequence of avoidance, though it could also reflect low assertiveness in accommodation.

items.text: I don't think it's my place to bring up problems—if it matters enough, someone else will.
items.rationale: Deferring responsibility for raising issues is avoidant, though the passivity could overlap with accommodation.

items.text: I'd rather not say anything about a disagreement and just let the other person have what they want.
items.rationale: Silence plus yielding blends avoidance (not engaging) with accommodation (letting the other person win).

items.text: When I'm in a disagreement, I try to find a solution that fully satisfies everyone involved.
items.rationale: Seeking full satisfaction for all parties is the defining goal of the collaborating style.

items.text: I enjoy working through conflicts because they often lead to creative solutions neither side originally considered.
items.rationale: Viewing conflict as an opportunity for creative problem-solving is a hallmark of collaboration.

items.text: I make a point of understanding the other person's underlying concerns before proposing any solution.
items.rationale: Deep exploration of others' concerns reflects the integrative information-sharing process of collaboration.

items.text: I believe the best outcomes come when both sides openly share what they really need.
items.rationale: Valuing open mutual disclosure of needs is a core belief underlying the collaborative approach.

items.text: I'm willing to spend extra time on a disagreement if it means we can find a win-win outcome.
items.rationale: Investing time for mutual gain reflects the high effort and integrative orientation of collaboration.

items.text: During conflicts, I actively look for ways to merge my ideas with the other person's ideas.
items.rationale: Merging ideas from both sides is the integrative problem-solving process central to collaboration.

items.text: I ask a lot of questions during disagreements because I want to truly understand the other person's perspective.
items.rationale: Active inquiry into others' perspectives is a key behavioral component of collaboration.

items.text: I don't think anyone should have to give up something important—there's usually a way to address everyone's core needs.
items.rationale: Rejecting trade-offs in favor of integrative solutions is the philosophical foundation of collaboration.

items.text: I see conflict as a problem to be solved together, not a battle to be won.
items.rationale: Framing conflict as joint problem-solving rather than competition is quintessentially collaborative.

items.text: I encourage people to put all their concerns on the table so we can work through them systematically.
items.rationale: Facilitating full disclosure and systematic resolution reflects collaborative process management.

items.text: I'm not satisfied with a resolution unless both parties feel their most important needs have been met.
items.rationale: Setting mutual satisfaction as the success criterion is the defining standard of collaboration.

items.text: When I disagree with someone, I try to dig beneath the surface positions to find shared interests.
items.rationale: Moving from positions to interests is a classic integrative negotiation technique central to collaboration.

items.text: I think most conflicts can be resolved if people are willing to be honest and creative together.
items.rationale: While reflecting collaborative values, this is somewhat aspirational and could reflect idealism rather than actual behavior.

items.text: I try to find middle ground that addresses at least some of what each person wants.
items.rationale: Finding middle ground with partial satisfaction could reflect compromising (splitting the difference) rather than true collaboration (full integration).

items.text: I like to explore multiple options before settling on a resolution, even if it takes longer.
items.rationale: Exploring options is collaborative, but the emphasis on process without explicit mention of mutual satisfaction introduces slight ambiguity.

items.text: When I'm in a conflict, my primary goal is to win.
items.rationale: An explicit win orientation is the most direct expression of the competing style.

items.text: I believe that in most disagreements, one person is right and the other is wrong—and I'm usually right.
items.rationale: A zero-sum view of conflict combined with self-confidence in one's correctness is core to competing.

items.text: I use whatever leverage I have to make sure my position prevails in a dispute.
items.rationale: Using power and leverage to prevail is a defining tactic of the competing style.

items.text: I don't back down in arguments because showing weakness invites people to take advantage of you.
items.rationale: Equating concession with weakness and vulnerability reflects the competitive mindset.

items.text: I'm very direct about what I want and I push hard to get it, even if it creates friction.
items.rationale: High assertiveness with willingness to create friction is a behavioral hallmark of competing.

items.text: I'd rather be respected for my strength than liked for being easy to get along with.
items.rationale: Prioritizing respect through strength over likability reflects the value system of the competing style.

items.text: If someone challenges my position, I take it as a signal to argue my case even harder.
items.rationale: Escalating assertiveness in response to challenge is a classic competing response pattern.

items.text: I see negotiations as something you either win or lose, and I intend to win.
items.rationale: An explicit zero-sum framing of negotiation with a win orientation is quintessentially competitive.

items.text: People sometimes describe me as aggressive or domineering during disagreements.
items.rationale: Being perceived as aggressive or domineering is a common social consequence of the competing style.

items.text: I have no problem overriding someone else's objections if I know my approach is the best one.
items.rationale: Overriding objections based on self-assessed superiority reflects high assertiveness and low cooperativeness.

items.text: In a conflict, I focus on making my case as persuasive as possible rather than listening to the other side.
items.rationale: Prioritizing persuasion over listening reflects the one-directional influence strategy of competing.

items.text: I think being decisive and firm is more important than making everyone comfortable.
items.rationale: Valuing decisiveness over others' comfort reflects the assertive, low-cooperativeness dimension of competing.

items.text: I stand my ground firmly but I'm open to hearing what the other person has to say.
items.rationale: Firmness is competitive, but openness to hearing others introduces some collaborative or compromising elements.

items.text: I advocate strongly for my position, but I'm willing to adjust if the other person makes a compelling case.
items.rationale: Strong advocacy is competitive, but willingness to adjust based on merit could reflect collaborating or compromising.

items.text: I'm not afraid to assert myself, though I do try to be fair about it.
items.rationale: Assertiveness is competitive, but the fairness qualifier introduces ambiguity with compromising.

items.text: I think the fairest way to resolve a disagreement is for each side to give up something.
items.rationale: Mutual concession as a fairness principle is the philosophical core of the compromising style.

items.text: I usually look for a middle-ground solution that both parties can live with.
items.rationale: Seeking middle ground with acceptable (not optimal) outcomes is the defining strategy of compromising.

items.text: I'm willing to give up some of what I want if the other person does the same.
items.rationale: Reciprocal concession is the fundamental mechanism of the compromising style.

items.text: I believe that splitting the difference is usually the quickest and most practical way to settle a dispute.
items.rationale: Splitting the difference as a practical expedient is a classic compromising strategy.

items.text: A good resolution is one where nobody gets everything they want, but everyone gets something.
items.rationale: Defining good resolution as partial satisfaction for all is the compromising standard of success.

items.text: I'd rather reach a quick, reasonable agreement than spend a long time searching for the perfect solution.
items.rationale: Valuing speed and reasonableness over optimality reflects the pragmatic efficiency of compromising.

items.text: When negotiations stall, I suggest we each make a concession to move things forward.
items.rationale: Proposing mutual concessions to break deadlocks is a prototypical compromising tactic.

items.text: I think being flexible and meeting people halfway is a sign of maturity.
items.rationale: Valuing meeting halfway as a virtue reflects the compromising value system.

items.text: I often propose a 50-50 split when I can't see an obvious way to resolve a disagreement.
items.rationale: Defaulting to equal splits is a concrete behavioral expression of the compromising approach.

items.text: I don't mind making trade-offs as long as the other person is making them too.
items.rationale: Conditional willingness to trade off based on reciprocity is central to compromising.

items.text: I try to find a resolution that's good enough for everyone rather than perfect for anyone.
items.rationale: Satisficing rather than optimizing is the pragmatic hallmark of the compromising style.

items.text: In most conflicts, I think both sides need to bend a little to reach an agreement.
items.rationale: Expecting mutual bending reflects the balanced concession expectation of compromising.

items.text: I prefer a practical solution now over an ideal solution that might never happen.
items.rationale: Pragmatism over idealism is compromising, but could also reflect a general decisiveness unrelated to conflict style.

items.text: I try to make sure both sides walk away with at least their most important needs addressed.
items.rationale: Addressing most important needs for both sides could reflect compromising (partial satisfaction) or collaborating (integrative satisfaction of core needs).

items.text: I think reasonable people should be able to find a fair deal without too much fuss.
items.rationale: Emphasis on fairness and efficiency is compromising, but 'without too much fuss' could hint at avoidance of deep engagement.
